thread.title: ASIC notes rise in suspicious activity reporting
thread.title_full: ASIC notes rise in suspicious activity reporting

title: ASIC notes rise in suspicious activity reporting
text:
So far in 2015, some 55 suspicious trading incidents have been reported,. Photo: Sasha Wooley
The Australian Securities and Investments Commission has seen a rise in the reporting of suspicious trading activity under its market integrity rules.
Participants of the Australian Securities Exchange and Chi-X must notify the regulator if they have "reasonable grounds" to suspect an order or transaction has been placed while an individual in possession of inside information.
In addition, they may report activity which has the effect of creating or maintaining an artificial price or a false or misleading appearance in the market or price for trading in financial products.
The suspicious activity reporting (SAR) rule came into effect in January 2013, with ASIC receiving 214 such reports from 34 market participants since.
Advertisement Of those reports, one market participant was responsible for almost 11 per cent of the total.
So far in 2015, some 55 suspicious trading incidents have been reported, suggesting another annual rise in the reports to ASIC.
The year-to-date figure compares to 84 reports to ASIC for calendar 2014 and 75 in 2013.
"The importance of SAR to ASIC is reflected in the number of reported matters being referred to ASIC's Enforcement team for further investigation," the regulator said in a supervisory update.
"Approximately 15 per cent of SARs received to date have been referred to enforcement for further investigation."
